topic: Introduction to Shakespeare: The Man, the Myth, the Theater
prior_knowledge: Students have completed Unit 1: Greek Theater and Unit 2: Commedia dell'Arte. They understand theatrical origins, use of masks, improvisation, stock characters, and physical comedy.

standards.full_text: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in the text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including words with multiple meanings or language that is particularly fresh, engaging, or beautiful. (Include Shakespeare as well as other authors.)
Analyze how an author draws on and transforms source material in a specific work.

learning_objectives: Describe Shakespeare's life, career, and historical context in Elizabethan England
Explain the structure and audience of the Globe Theatre
Define key theatrical terms: groundlings, soliloquy, aside

vocabulary.definition: The open-air playhouse in London where Shakespeare's company performed; built 1599, rebuilt after fire in 1614
vocabulary.usage_example: When you stood in the yard of the Globe Theatre, you were just feet away from the actors—closer than any movie theater seat.

vocabulary.definition: Audience members who paid a penny to stand in the yard in front of the stage; typically working-class theatergoers
vocabulary.usage_example: The groundlings would cheer, boo, and throw things at the stage—they were the most active part of Shakespeare's audience.

vocabulary.definition: A line of verse containing five metrical feet, each consisting of an unstressed syllable followed by a stressed syllable (da-DUM da-DUM da-DUM da-DUM da-DUM)
vocabulary.usage_example: Listen to the rhythm: 'But SOFT, what LIGHT through YONder WINdow BREAKS'—that's iambic pentameter, Shakespeare's signature beat.

vocabulary.definition: A speech in which a character speaks their thoughts aloud while alone on stage, revealing their inner feelings to the audience
vocabulary.usage_example: Hamlet's 'To be or not to be' is a soliloquy—he's sharing his deepest thoughts directly with us, the audience.

vocabulary.definition: A remark made by a character intended for the audience but supposedly not heard by other characters on stage
vocabulary.usage_example: When a villain turns to the audience and whispers 'Little does she know...' that's an aside—a secret shared only with the audience.

warmup.name: Tongue Twisters and Projection
warmup.instructions: Students practice three tongue twisters: 1) 'She sells seashells by the seashore' 2) 'Unique New York' 3) 'Red leather, yellow leather'. First quietly, then projecting to the back of the room. Focus on clear articulation even at volume.
warmup.connection_to_lesson: Shakespeare's actors needed to project in open-air theaters without microphones, and his language demands clear articulation to be understood.

activity.name: Myth vs. Reality: What Do We Really Know About Shakespeare?
activity.instructions: In groups of 3-4, students receive an envelope with 10 'facts' about Shakespeare. 5 are true, 5 are myths. Groups must sort them and explain their reasoning. After 10 minutes, teacher reveals answers. Discussion: What do we actually know about Shakespeare? What remains mysterious? Why does it matter?
materials_needed: Envelopes with fact cards (1 set per group)

differentiation.ell: Provide glossary for difficult vocabulary in fact cards; assign group roles
differentiation.advanced: Additional challenge: Create one additional myth and one fact to share with class
differentiation.struggling: Reduce to 6 facts (3 true, 3 myth); provide hint sheet

myth_vs_fact_cards.statement: Shakespeare was born in Stratford-upon-Avon in 1564

myth_vs_fact_cards.answer: MYTH - he likely attended King's New School

myth_vs_fact_cards.statement: Shakespeare married Anne Hathaway when he was 18
Shakespeare wrote all his plays alone without collaboration
myth_vs_fact_cards.answer: MYTH - he collaborated on several plays

myth_vs_fact_cards.statement: Shakespeare was an actor as well as a playwright

myth_vs_fact_cards.answer: FACT - first appears in Merchant of Venice

myth_vs_fact_cards.statement: Shakespeare was always famous during his lifetime
myth_vs_fact_cards.answer: MYTH - his fame grew significantly after death

myth_vs_fact_cards.statement: The original Globe Theatre is still standing today
myth_vs_fact_cards.answer: MYTH - it burned down in 1613; current Globe is a reconstruction

journal_prompt: Shakespeare wrote over 400 years ago, yet we still perform, study, and adapt his work today. Why do you think his plays have lasted so long? What makes a story 'timeless'?
exit_tickets: What was the Globe Theatre and when was it built?
Who were the 'groundlings' and where did they watch plays?
What is a soliloquy and how does it differ from dialogue?
content_points: William Shakespeare was born in Stratford-upon-Avon in 1564
He married Anne Hathaway at 18; they had three children
The 'Lost Years' (1585-1592) - we don't know what he was doing
By 1592 he was established in London as actor and playwright
He was part owner of the Lord Chamberlain's Men (later King's Men)
The Globe Theatre was built in 1599 on the south bank of the Thames
The Globe was an open-air theater holding about 3,000 people
Groundlings stood in the yard for a penny; wealthier patrons sat in galleries
Performances were in the afternoon using natural light
All female roles were played by boys/young men
Shakespeare wrote approximately 37 plays and 154 sonnets
He died on April 23, 1616, in Stratford

formative: Myth vs. Reality sorting accuracy and reasoning
assessment_connections.summative: Unit 3 Performance Assessment: Shakespeare Scene Analysis and Performance (end of Unit 3)

content_accuracy_notes.historical_context: Shakespeare's exact birthdate is unknown; April 23 is traditional based on his baptism date. The 'Lost Years' remain a subject of scholarly debate.
content_accuracy_notes.romeo_juliet_comparison: Reference Baz Luhrmann's 1996 film as a widely-known example of a bold directorial concept (modern setting, original language) vs. traditional period staging—useful for later directing discussions.
